title: German submarine U-591
text:
German submarine "U-591" was a <a href="German%20Type%20VIIC%20submarine">Type VIIC</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> built for <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s "<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>" for service during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
She was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 30 October 1940 by <a href="Blohm%20%26amp%3B%20Voss">Blohm & Voss</a>, <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a> as yard number 567, <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 20 August 1941 and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 9 October 1941 under "<a href="Kapit%C3%A4nleutnant">Kapitänleutnant</a>" Hans-Jürgen Zetzsche.
Design.
<a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">German Type VIIC submarines</a> were preceded by the shorter <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIB">Type VIIB submarines</a>. "U-591" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a total length of , a <a href="pressure%20hull">pressure hull</a> length of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of , a height of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by two <a href="Germaniawerft">Germaniawerft</a> F46 four-stroke, six-cylinder <a href="supercharged">supercharged</a> <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s producing a total of for use while surfaced, two <a href="Brown%2C%20Boveri%20%26amp%3B%20Cie">Brown, Boveri & Cie</a> GG UB 720/8 <a href="Motor%E2%80%93generator">double-acting electric motors</a> producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two <a href="propeller">propeller</a>s. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-591" was fitted with five <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s (four fitted at the bow and one at the stern), fourteen <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es, one <a href="8.8%20cm%20SK%20C/35%20naval%20gun">SK C/35 naval gun</a>, 220 rounds, and a <a href="2%20cm%20FlaK%2030">C/30</a> anti-aircraft gun. The boat had a <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> of between forty-four and sixty.
Service history.
The boat's service began on 9 October 1941 with training, followed by active service as part of the <a href="6th%20U-boat%20Flotilla">6th U-boat Flotilla</a>. She was transferred to the <a href="11th%20U-boat%20Flotilla">11th Flotilla</a> on 1 July 1942 for active service in the <a href="North%20Atlantic">North Atlantic</a> operating out of <a href="Bergen">Bergen</a>. The following year, on 1 June 1943, she transferred to <a href="9th%20U-boat%20Flotilla">9th Flotilla</a> operating of <a href="Brest%2C%20France">Brest, France</a>.
In 4 patrols she sank four merchant ships, for a total of , plus one merchant ship damaged.
Wolfpacks.
U-591 took part in nine <a href="Wolfpack%20%28naval%20tactic%29">wolfpacks</a>, namely
Convoy ONS 154.
The first victim of <a href="Convoy%20ONS%20154">Convoy ONS 154</a> was the 5,701-GRT Norwegian freighter "Norse King", the second in column eleven, on 28 December 1942. "U-591" torpedo hit her at 20:04. Badly damaged, "Norse King" attempted to limp to the <a href="Azores">Azores</a> but was found by and sent to the bottom.
"U-591"’s second success was the badly damaged and abandoned 4,871-GRT <a href="United%20Africa%20Company">United Africa Company</a> freighter "Zarian" with a single torpedo, although she missed the "Baron Cochrane"
Convoy SC 121.
Having recently returned to sea after a long recovery from gunshot wounds, Hans-Jürgen Zetzsche was on target with <a href="Convoy%20SC%20121">Convoy SC 121</a> when he sighted the "Empire Impala", hove-to picking up survivors from the torpedoed "Egyptian", on 7 March 1943. Of the combined crew of 80 men, from both "Egyptian" and "Empire Impala", only 3 survived.
Fate.
"U-591" was sunk on 30 July 1943 in the <a href="South%20Atlantic">South Atlantic</a> near <a href="Pernambuco">Pernambuco</a> in position ; depth charged by a US <a href="Lockheed%20Ventura">Lockheed Ventura</a> aircraft of <a href="VPB-127">VB-127</a>. There were 19 dead and 28 survivors.
